Name: Hydrogen
Origin of name: Greek elements hydro- and -gen, 'water-forming'

Name: Helium
Origin of name: Greek hḗlios, 'sun'

Name: Lithium
Origin of name: Greek líthos, 'stone'

Name: Beryllium
Origin of name: Beryl, a mineral (ultimately from the name of Belur in southern India)

Name: Boron
Origin of name: Borax, a mineral (from Arabic bawraq, Middle Persian *bōrag)

Name: Carbon
Origin of name: Latin carbo, 'coal'

Name: Nitrogen
Origin of name: Greek nítron and -gen, 'niter-forming'

Name: Oxygen
Origin of name: Greek oxy- and -gen, 'acid-forming'

Name: Fluorine
Origin of name: Latin fluere, 'to flow'

Name: Neon
Origin of name: Greek néon, 'new'

Name: Sodium
Origin of name: Coined by Humphry Davy who first isolated it, from English soda (specifically caustic soda), via Italian from Arabic ṣudāʕ 'headache' ·  Symbol Na is derived from Neo-Latin natrium, coined from German Natron, 'natron'

Name: Magnesium
Origin of name: Magnesia, a district of Eastern Thessaly in Greece

Name: Aluminium
Origin of name: Alumina, from Latin alumen (gen. aluminis), 'bitter salt, alum'

Name: Silicon
Origin of name: Latin silex, 'flint' (originally silicium)

Name: Phosphorus
Origin of name: Greek phōsphóros, 'light-bearing'

Name: Sulfur
Origin of name: Latin

Name: Chlorine
Origin of name: Greek chlōrós, 'greenish yellow'

Name: Argon
Origin of name: Greek argós, 'idle' (because of its inertness)

Name: Potassium
Origin of name: Neo-Latin potassa, 'potash', itself from pot and ash ·  Symbol K is derived from Neo-Latin kalium, from German

Name: Calcium
Origin of name: Latin calx, 'lime'

Name: Scandium
Origin of name: Latin Scandia, 'Scandinavia'

Name: Titanium
Origin of name: Titans, the sons of the earth goddess of Greek mythology

Name: Vanadium
Origin of name: Vanadis, an Old Norse name for the Scandinavian goddess Freyja

Name: Chromium
Origin of name: Greek chróma, 'colour'

Name: Manganese
Origin of name: Corrupted from magnesia negra; see § magnesium

Name: Iron
Origin of name: English, from Proto-Celtic *īsarnom ('iron'), from a root meaning 'blood' ·  Symbol Fe is derived from Latin ferrum

Name: Cobalt
Origin of name: German Kobold, 'goblin'

Name: Nickel
Origin of name: Nickel, a mischievous sprite of German miner mythology

Name: Copper
Origin of name: English, from Latin cuprum, from Ancient Greek Kýpros 'Cyprus'

Name: Zinc
Origin of name: Most likely from German Zinke, 'prong' or 'tooth', though some suggest Persian sang, 'stone'

Name: Gallium
Origin of name: Latin Gallia, 'France'

Name: Germanium
Origin of name: Latin Germania, 'Germany'

Name: Arsenic
Origin of name: Middle English, from Middle French arsenic, from Greek arsenikón 'yellow arsenic' (influenced by arsenikós, 'masculine' or 'virile'), from a West Asian wanderword ultimately from Old Iranian *zarniya-ka, 'golden'

Name: Selenium
Origin of name: Greek selḗnē, 'moon'

Name: Bromine
Origin of name: Greek brômos, 'stench'

Name: Krypton
Origin of name: Greek kryptós, 'hidden'

Name: Rubidium
Origin of name: Latin rubidus, 'deep red'

Name: Strontium
Origin of name: Strontian, a village in Scotland, where it was found

Name: Yttrium
Origin of name: Ytterby, Sweden, where it was found; see also terbium, erbium, ytterbium

Name: Zirconium
Origin of name: Zircon, a mineral, from Persian zargun, 'gold-hued'

Name: Niobium
Origin of name: Niobe, daughter of king Tantalus from Greek mythology; see also tantalum

Name: Molybdenum
Origin of name: Greek molýbdaina, 'piece of lead', from mólybdos, 'lead', due to confusion with lead ore galena (PbS)

Name: Technetium
Origin of name: Greek tekhnētós, 'artificial'

Name: Ruthenium
Origin of name: Neo-Latin Ruthenia, 'Russia'

Name: Rhodium
Origin of name: Greek rhodóeis, 'rose-coloured', from rhódon, 'rose'

Name: Palladium
Origin of name: Pallas, an asteroid, considered a planet at the time

Name: Silver
Origin of name: English, from a common Germanic root ·  Symbol Ag is derived from Latin argentum

Name: Cadmium
Origin of name: Neo-Latin cadmia, 'calamine', from King Kadmos, legendary founder of Thebes

Name: Indium
Origin of name: Latin indicum, 'indigo', the blue colour found in its spectrum

Name: Tin
Origin of name: English, from a common Germanic root ·  Symbol Sn is derived from Latin stannum

Name: Antimony
Origin of name: Latin antimonium, the origin of which is uncertain: folk etymologies suggest it is derived from Greek antí ('against') + mónos ('alone'), or Old French anti-moine, 'Monk's bane', but it could plausibly be from or related to Arabic ʾiṯmid, 'antimony', reformatted as a Latin word ·  Symbol Sb is derived from Latin stibium 'stibnite'

Name: Tellurium
Origin of name: Latin tellus, 'the ground, earth'

Name: Iodine
Origin of name: French iode, from Greek ioeidḗs, 'violet'

Name: Xenon
Origin of name: Greek xénon, neuter form of xénos 'strange, foreign'

Name: Caesium
Origin of name: Latin caesius, 'sky-blue'

Name: Barium
Origin of name: Greek barýs, 'heavy'

Name: Lanthanum
Origin of name: Greek lanthánein, 'to lie hidden'

Name: Cerium
Origin of name: Ceres, a dwarf planet, considered a planet at the time

Name: Praseodymium
Origin of name: Greek prásios dídymos, 'green twin'

Name: Neodymium
Origin of name: Greek néos dídymos, 'new twin'

Name: Promethium
Origin of name: Prometheus, a figure in Greek mythology

Name: Samarium
Origin of name: Samarskite, a mineral named after V. Samarsky-Bykhovets, Russian mine official

Name: Europium
Origin of name: Europe

Name: Gadolinium
Origin of name: Gadolinite, a mineral named after Johan Gadolin, Finnish chemist, physicist and mineralogist

Name: Terbium
Origin of name: Ytterby, Sweden, where it was found; see also yttrium, erbium, ytterbium

Name: Dysprosium
Origin of name: Greek dysprósitos, 'hard to get'

Name: Holmium
Origin of name: Neo-Latin Holmia, 'Stockholm'

Name: Erbium
Origin of name: Ytterby, Sweden, where it was found; see also yttrium, terbium, ytterbium

Name: Thulium
Origin of name: Thule, the ancient name for an unclear northern location

Name: Ytterbium
Origin of name: Ytterby, Sweden, where it was found; see also yttrium, terbium, erbium

Name: Lutetium
Origin of name: Latin Lutetia', 'Paris'

Name: Hafnium
Origin of name: Neo-Latin Hafnia, 'Copenhagen' (from Danish havn, harbour)

Name: Tantalum
Origin of name: King Tantalus, father of Niobe from Greek mythology; see also niobium

Name: Tungsten
Origin of name: Swedish tung sten, 'heavy stone' ·  Symbol W is from Wolfram, originally from Middle High German wolf-rahm 'wolf's foam' describing the mineral wolframite

Name: Rhenium
Origin of name: Latin Rhenus, 'Rhine'

Name: Osmium
Origin of name: Greek osmḗ, 'smell'

Name: Iridium
Origin of name: Iris, the Greek goddess of the rainbow

Name: Platinum
Origin of name: Spanish platina, 'little silver', from plata 'silver'

Name: Gold
Origin of name: English, from the same Proto-Indo-European root as 'yellow' ·  Symbol Au is derived from Latin aurum

Name: Mercury
Origin of name: Mercury, Roman god of commerce, communication, and luck, known for his speed and mobility ·  Symbol Hg is derived from its Latin name hydrargyrum, from Greek hydrárgyros, 'water-silver'

Name: Thallium
Origin of name: Greek thallós, 'green shoot or twig'

Name: Lead
Origin of name: English, from Proto-Celtic *ɸloudom, from a root meaning 'flow' ·  Symbol Pb is derived from Latin plumbum

Name: Bismuth
Origin of name: German Wismut, via Latin and Arabic from Greek psimúthion, 'white lead'

Name: Polonium
Origin of name: Latin Polonia, 'Poland', home country of Marie Curie, who discovered it

Name: Astatine
Origin of name: Greek ástatos, 'unstable', alluding to its lack of stable isotopes

Name: Radon
Origin of name: Radium emanation, originally the name of the isotope radon-222

Name: Francium
Origin of name: France, home country of discoverer Marguerite Perey

Name: Radium
Origin of name: Coined in French by discoverer Marie Curie, from Latin radius, 'ray'

Name: Actinium
Origin of name: Greek aktís, 'ray'

Name: Thorium
Origin of name: Thor, the Scandinavian god of thunder

Name: Protactinium
Origin of name: English prefix proto- (from Greek prôtos, 'first, before') + actinium, since actinium is produced through the radioactive decay of protactinium

Name: Uranium
Origin of name: Uranus, the seventh planet in the Solar System

Name: Neptunium
Origin of name: Neptune, the eighth planet in the Solar System

Name: Plutonium
Origin of name: Pluto, a dwarf planet in the Solar System, considered a planet at the time

Name: Americium
Origin of name: The Americas, where the element was first synthesised, by analogy with its homologue § europium

Name: Curium
Origin of name: Pierre Curie and Marie Curie, French physicists and chemists

Name: Berkelium
Origin of name: Berkeley, California, where the element was first synthesised

Name: Californium
Origin of name: California, where the element was first synthesised in the LBNL laboratory

Name: Einsteinium
Origin of name: Albert Einstein, German physicist

Name: Fermium
Origin of name: Enrico Fermi, Italian physicist

Name: Mendelevium
Origin of name: Dmitri Mendeleev, Russian chemist who proposed the periodic table

Name: Nobelium
Origin of name: Alfred Nobel, Swedish chemist and engineer

Name: Lawrencium
Origin of name: Ernest Lawrence, American physicist

Name: Rutherfordium
Origin of name: Ernest Rutherford, chemist and physicist from New Zealand

Name: Dubnium
Origin of name: Dubna, Russia, where the element was discovered in the JINR laboratory

Name: Seaborgium
Origin of name: Glenn T. Seaborg, American chemist

Name: Bohrium
Origin of name: Niels Bohr, Danish physicist

Name: Hassium
Origin of name: Neo-Latin Hassia, 'Hesse', a state in Germany

Name: Meitnerium
Origin of name: Lise Meitner, Austrian physicist

Name: Darmstadtium
Origin of name: Darmstadt, Germany, where the element was first synthesised in the GSI laboratories

Name: Roentgenium
Origin of name: Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen, German physicist

Name: Copernicium
Origin of name: Nicolaus Copernicus, Polish astronomer

Name: Nihonium
Origin of name: Japanese Nihon, 'Japan', where the element was first synthesised in the Riken laboratories

Name: Flerovium
Origin of name: Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions, part of JINR, where the element was synthesised; itself named after Georgy Flyorov, Russian physicist

Name: Moscovium
Origin of name: Moscow, Russia, where the element was first synthesised in the JINR laboratories

Name: Livermorium
Origin of name: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in Livermore, California

Name: Tennessine
Origin of name: Tennessee, United States, where Oak Ridge National Laboratory is located

Name: Oganesson
Origin of name: Yuri Oganessian, Russian physicist
